channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [DERBY-2635] intermittent failure in T_RawStoreFactory unit test
item.description:
I have seen the following intermittent error at least 3 times in my environment. I am really interest to know if anyone else is seeing it - or maybe I just have
a flakey disk/hardware. The underlying problem of an interrupt causing a nio failure I believe is reported somewhere else but I have no idea why this unit
test is the only thing to see it in my environment - never any other test . This was encountered when running the entire set of tests, each time.

The diff is:

                  • Diff file derbyall/storeall/storeunit/T_RawStoreFactory.diff
      • Start: T_RawStoreFactory jdk1.5.0 storeall:storeunit 2007-05-10 15:27:49 ***
        2 del
        < – Unit Test T_RawStoreFactory finished
        2 add
        > Shutting down due to unit test failure.
        Test Failed.
      • End: T_RawStoreFactory jdk1.5.0 storeall:storeunit 2007-05-10 15:28:30 ***

The interesting stack from the derby.log is:

item.summary: intermittent failure in T_RawStoreFactory unit test

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Attaching full derby.log from the failed unit test found in:
derby/derbyall/storeall/storeunit/storeunit/derby.log

This could be a side effect of my last patch for DERBY-2107. That patch adds an assert which makes one of the test cases in T_RawStoreFactory fail immediately in sane mode instead of hanging until it is interrupted. Perhaps that is causing an interrupt to be sent to a subsequent test case?

You could try to disable the interrupter thread in T_Util.t_checkGetLatchedPage() in sane builds and see if that makes the problem go away.
Attaching patch which fixes the test by disabling the interrupter thread in sane builds. I have run the test 100 times without seeing the error (without the patch it failed every ~10 runs).
